comments:
This course addresses the public perceptions and attitudes concerning the causes
and importance of global. This course provides a sound theoretical understanding of
global warming through an appreciation of the Earth's climate system and how and why
this has changed through time. The course describes progress in the understanding of the
human and natural drivers of climate change, climate processes and attribution, and
estimates of projected future climate change. The course also assesses scientific,
technical and socio- economic information relevant for the understanding of climate
change, its potential impacts and options for adaptation and mitigation.
This course is interesting and relevant to today's issues. An excellent class that
will make any student extremely knowledgeable on the science of global climate change,
not to mention earth system dynamics.
Dr. Marinov was considered extremely knowledgeable, and in addition to the
course material, taught students a little about the process of research and studying climate
science itself. This course was said to have a balance between covering a breadth of
topics and going into depth on individual topics.
Many former students believe it is possible for a student without any relevant
prior coursework to do well in this course; however this will require a lot of work in
terms of understanding the readings and the materials covered. Students found the exams
to be challenging due to the fact that the grading criteria were very strict, looking for very
specific answers to broad questions.
*Based on 10 student reviews
